legacy.full_text:
Huh. Looks like Plato was right.

A new paper shows all language models converge on the same "universal geometry" of meaning. Researchers can translate between ANY model's embeddings without seeing the original text.

Implications for philosophy and vector databases alike. https://t.co/AINeTddgdW

result.text:
the Platonic Representations paper (great thread by Carlos) has been nagging me

on the one hand, I am a sucker for symmetry and elegance. this is that, and I love it.

on the other, I have long feared the outcome of a single totalizing AI. my hope rests in a proliferation of open source models, decentralizing power from who or whatever controls the One. Llama has given me great optimism in this regard

however, if all models converge on one representation, is this not a totalizing and centralizing paradigm?

regardless of how distributed their implementations and instantiations are, if their world models converge to a single representation this would be a highly centralizing force

legacy.full_text: @emollick Basically everything is intrinsically a non-linear reciprocal integral triplet. Input State >> Process State >> Output State. What is that? A triangle. The most fundamental unit of principle in our universe. Naturally this will be reflected in LLM and any AI.

result.text:
this is like saying because we can translate english and spanish there exists some universal platonic language...

there's nothing analytical about the isometry they are implying between the 2 manifolds. 

this is more kantian in the sense the implied *universal* (pardon the weak analogy) manifold/structure is noumenal--only mediated and embodied. it's existence merely *implied* by the isometric mapping they found.

also there is no proof that the isometry they find is *unique*, unlike plato's forms. 

there's so much ontologically misguided by the way ML researchers coopt philosophy verbiage.
